Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: The Impact of Trauma on Economic Preferences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RAPID project, the Principal Investigators will examine the effects of trauma from the violence of war on risk aversion and other economic attitudes by conducting economic experiments in Afghanistan. The team has preliminary results showing that Afghans who live near a bombing site, when primed to recall a fearful event, are willing to pay far more for certainty in an economic trade-off than is predicted by mainstream economic theory. This project will extend this work to examine the effects of trauma on all of the "Big 5" core factors that significantly shape economic behavior: tolerance for risk, patience and time discounting, social preferences, competitive propensity, and strategic sophistication. These changes in economic attitude can turn individuals away from otherwise beneficial economic opportunities and, society-wide, harm prospects for recovery.

In terms of broader impacts, this research will reveal how exposure to violence can dramatically influence many aspects of an individual's economic decision making. The project will also attempt to demonstrate the potential for simple economic instruments to act as diagnostic tools for economists and policy makers to identify potentially at-risk individuals, especially in transitional economies. While conducted with Afghans, these experiments may shed light on the effects of trauma on anyone exposed to violence, including members of the U.S. military and victims of violent crime. More broadly, this work may show shifts in economic attitudes that can have implications for the development and economic growth prospects of war-torn societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project supported two studies. The first study linked traumatic experiences to economic decisions in Afghanistan. The second study looked at the preferences and decisions of an important class of government workers in Pakistan: polio vaccinators.

The first study examined the impact of trauma on economic decisions that involve risk.  We measured risk by asking a large sample of Afghans from across the north and the west of the country to make hypothetical decisions involving uncertain outcomes. We then combined this data with precisely geocoded data on where attacks had occurred since the NATO-led invasion began in 2001. Last, we asked a randomly selected subset of respondents in our survey to provide a brief description of the causes of anxiety in their life, in effect priming them to think of violence before they engaged in hypothetical economic decisions involving uncertainty. We found that the combination of having experienced violence and having these experiences primed creates a strong preference for absolute certainty. A core theory of decisions under uncertainty, Expected Utility theory, predicts that there should be no premium placed on absolute certainty relative to near certainty. Our finding indicates that the combination of having experienced violence and being asked to recall these episodes has a clear impact on economic decisions.  Specifically, it causes subjects to value absolute certainty greatly. These findings have implications for policymakers and clinicians working to address the psychological effects of experiencing traumatic violence, and were published in the American Economic Review.

The second study focuses on understanding how to improve the wage contracts of an important class of government workers — polio vaccinators — using insights from behavioral decision theory.   Eliminating polio in Pakistan is a central global public health challenge, with Pakistan being one of three polio endemic countries in the world.  Our study involves a set of technological and incentive contract innovations aimed at making vaccination efforts more cost-effective.

Under the current immunization system, records of vaccination coverage remain unreliable and incomplete. Vaccinators are assigned an ambitiously large number of vaccinations to complete and so, predictably, miss their targets. Furthermore, it is nearly impossible for senior health officials to verify the activities of vaccinators. It is generally tacitly accepted that vaccinators will miss their mark substantially, but report that they have done so on the simple paper reporting forms required to verify coverage. Finally, vaccinators are currently paid a single lump sum for participation in a drive.

One policy option is to utilize pay-for-performance contracts, which are widely viewed as providing an important means of improving public sector performance. We are testing standard pay-for-performance contracts and examining whether modifying pay-for-performance contracts to account for vaccinators’ tendency to delay examinations can improve performance.

Additionally, systems for monitoring of polio vaccinators in Pakistan are weak, leading to limited accountability. Moreover, essential data processing systems describing the degree of current coverage and the need for future vaccinations are underdeveloped. Our system improves on the status quo by incentivizing vaccinations (each vaccination will be geo-stamped, time-stamped, and photographed), and by providing essential real-time data to policymakers using on-line dashboards.
